https://carsandbids.com/auctions/rxP2zza.auction_subtitle: Open-Top Bronco, 5-Speed Manual Swap, Some Additional Modifications
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/rxP2zza.dougs_take: OK, this is pretty cool. Everyone knows the giant enclosed panel over the rear seats in the 1990s Bronco lifts off, but practically no one has detached it or removed it, as it's tremendously heavy – and there's no roof to put in its place. Well, this Bronco ditched the rear roof, so now it offers an open-air driving experience – AND it has a top, so rear passengers won't get rained on. It gets better: this Bronco has undergone a manual transmission swap, making it more engaging to drive (and likely a bit more responsive) – and it boasts the Bronco's larger 5.8-liter V8, too. This is a cool truck, and I'm happy to have it on Cars & Bids, as Bronco models from this era continue to get more desirable.
auction_highlights: The attached AutoCheck vehicle history report shows no accidents; it also shows that this Bronco has been registered in Idaho and Oregon since it was purchased.
This Bronco was built with an automatic, but it has been modified with a 5-speed manual transmission from an F-350 pickup. Ford did not offer the Windsor V8 with a manual in 1993.
Additional modifications include Mickey Thompson wheels wearing 35-inch Maxxis tires, a Kenwood head unit paired with aftermarket speakers, subwoofer, and equalizer, and a Softopper cloth roof.

The full-size Bronco was related to the F-Series pickup but differed in that it used a single body with a removable top over the rear passenger compartment. A major update came for the 1992 model year and the truck was produced through 1996.

Power comes from a 5.8-liter "Windsor" V8 — which was the top engine choice — producing 210 horsepower and 325 lb-ft of torque. Output is sent to the rear or all four wheels through a 5-speed manual gearbox on this particular Bronco.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/KPvbWgY.dougs_take: The Subaru Baja is a wonderful quirky vehicle – half wagon, half pickup truck, all weird and interesting. Like all Subarus at the time, Baja models came standard with all-wheel drive – and they also came standard with a 5-speed manual, a rare choice that this Baja includes. This one also looks to be in nice shape, and it has relatively low miles for a Baja, as these were often heavily used as light-duty workhorse haulers. Since the Baja was cancelled, it developed a cult following, and I'm thrilled to offer this one on Cars & Bids.

The Baja was Subaru's second foray into the pickup market, following the BRAT. It was based on the Outback, but with an open pickup bed and a fold-down "mid-gate" as well as a bed extender to increase its utility even more. The Sport was the entry-level naturally-aspirated version. Updates for 2005 included a small ride height increase for more off-road ability as well as an additional power outlet.

Power comes from the 2.5-liter "EJ253" flat-4, which produces 165 horsepower and 166 lb-ft of torque. It was new for the 2005 model year and sends power to all four wheels through a 5-speed manual transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9a4PXM5.auction_subtitle: NO RESERVE 1 Owner, Grey-Market W126, Straight-6 Engine
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9a4PXM5.dougs_take: The W126 is a famous vehicle in Mercedes-Benz history, combining the brand's solid build quality with a design that's iconic and highly distinctive. This is an interesting car, as it's a grey-market example in nice shape – but by far the most amazing thing about it is that it's a one-owner car, as the seller bought it new in Dusseldorf in 1984 and privately imported it to the States back when such a thing was legal. One-owner W126 models are basically impossible to find now, so this is a rare treat.
auction_highlights: This gray-market 280SE is being sold by its original owner, who purchased it new in Dusseldorf, Germany, in late 1984 and had it shipped to the United States in early 1985. He explains that he bought this car as a trophy after taking his company public. He provides additional details in a video titled "The Story" that's embedded below.

The seller notes this 280SE has been registered in Texas since 1985. The attached AutoCheck history report and the Carfax report shown in the gallery both start in 2007, and they show Texas registrations since. Neither lists an accident in this car's past.

Air conditioning, a catalytic converter, and an American-spec instrument cluster were installed before this 280SE left Germany. The odometer shows 131,310 miles, but the seller states it stopped working less than 100 miles ago after he reset the trip meter.

Modifications made to this 280SE include a newer Alpine CD player. It's equipped with 14-inch wheels, wood interior trim, and a sunroof, among other features, and it still wears the desirable European-spec lights and bumpers on both ends.

Mercedes-Benz introduced the W126 in Germany in 1979, though American sales didn't start until the 1981 model year, and it expanded the range during the 1980s. 6- and 8-cylinder models were offered, plus long- and short-wheelbase variants and a coupe called C126 internally. Available from 1979 to 1985, the short-wheelbase and fuel-injected 280SE was positioned near the bottom of the range. It was never officially sold in America, making it a rare sight that's sought-after by enthusiasts.
Power for this 280SE comes from a 2.8-liter straight-6, which produces 182 horsepower and 177 lb-ft of torque. It spins the rear wheels via a 4-speed automatic transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/98yBzOO.dougs_take: I know, I know – a Chrysler 200 is a bit of an odd duck on this website. But there's one Chrysler 200 that's a rather special car, and that's this one. An all-wheel drive family sedan is rare, and the 295-horsepower V6 made this car a standout for performance back in 2015 – and even today, as it does 0-to-60 in around 6 seconds. This car also comes loaded with tech and, personally, I always liked the look – especially with the big wheels from the "S" model.
auction_highlights: The seller's family purchased this Chrysler new in 2015 and he later acquired the car in 2018.
Unmodified, this 200S came equipped with 19-inch Hyper Black-finished alloy wheels, sport seats, the Premium Lighting Group, Navigation and Sound Group, and the Comfort Group.

The Chrysler 200 is a mid-sized sedan that was introduced in 2011 and was intended to compete with the Honda Accord and Toyota Camry. The second-generation model was built from 2015 to 2017, and the lineup included this sportier 200S model that boasted best-in-class V6 horsepower and the lowest drag coefficient. It's also distinguished by being the first car in its segment to offer a dial-based gear shifter.
Power comes from a "Pentastar" 3.6L V6 engine, which produces 295 horsepower and 262 lb-ft of torque. It's mated to a 9-speed automatic transmission and all-wheel-drive system.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/9lQEZjO.dougs_take: I always loved the look of CLK models from this era – clean, flowing lines and a simple, handsome design. This particular CLK offers V8 power, reasonably low mileage, and a convertible top – and its lifetime Southern ownership is a good sign that it hasn't been exposed to any nasty weather. These are a bargain compared to their original prices, and I'm happy to offer this on Cars & Bids.
auction_highlights: The attached AutoCheck history report confirms this CLK has been Florida-kept since new.

The original window sticker included in the gallery shows that this CLK cost $68,970 in 2004, and that it was ordered with $7,400 in optional equipment. Unmodified, it notably features the desirable Launch Edition package, which adds features like wood interior trim and heated front seats. It's also equipped with an AMG Design body kit and a power-operated black soft top.

The seller notes that the engine oil, the valve cover gaskets, the rear main seal, the engine mounts, the front and rear brakes, and the soft top's hydraulic cylinders were recently replaced. Receipts for the parts installed are shown in the gallery, and the seller adds that all of the work was performed by the Mercedes-Benz dealership he works at.

Mercedes-Benz introduced the second-generation CLK for the 2003 model year. It was based on the W203-generation C-Class, but its exterior styling brought it in line with the bigger E-Class. Engine options for the non-AMG-tuned model included a V6 (which represented the bulk of sales) and a much rarer V8. CLK sales ended after the 2009 model year, and the coupe and convertible variants were replaced by the two-door E-Class.
Power for this CLK comes from a 5.0-liter V8, which produces 302 horsepower and 339 lb-ft of torque. It spins the rear wheels via a 5-speed automatic transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/r4BqARO.dougs_take: Here's another absolutely BEAUTIFUL 850CSi from this seller, who appears to be a master at finding fantastic examples of this ultra-rare, ultra-special V12-powered BMW. These are cool cars and they're becoming radically more desirable as the years go on; the thrill of a naturally-aspirated, manual V12 is hard to beat – and the excitement of the 850CSi's ultra-low production number makes it even more alluring. I loved driving the 850CSi when I reviewed one years ago, and I completely understand why its values are increasing – it's a great car, and nice ones are hard to find.
auction_highlights: The attached AutoCheck vehicle history report shows no accidents in this car's past.
Included in the sale of this CSi are service documentation dating back to 1994, the car's original window sticker, three keys, owner's manuals, and several CSi publications.

Service addressed within the last year includes some cosmetic items — such as new interior door handles and a paint correction — and mechanical items like repairing seat twist on both front seats and an oil service. Several service documents are pictured in the photo gallery.
Modifications to this 850CSi are limited to a Dinan exhaust and a Dinan chipset, which reportedly increases power by 33 horsepower and 34 lb-ft of torque.

The "E31" 850CSi — which stands for "Coupe Sport injection" — was BMW's flagship in the 1990s. Developed by BMW Motorsport, the CSi stood atop the standard 8 Series range as the high-performance model, complete with a thoroughly revised 5.6-liter V12 engine. Other M upgrades made to the CSi included a specific body kit with more aerodynamic bumpers, stronger front hubs, a firmer and lower suspension, a quicker steering rack, and smaller details such as Motorsports door handles, red instrument needles, an M-specific VIN, plus a "Powered by M" engine cover.

This 850CSi is powered by the "S70B56" 5.6-liter V12, which — in stock form — produces 375 horsepower and 420 lb-ft of torque. This particularly CSi may produce more, but no dyno sheet was provided to confirm.

BMW sold 2,363 units of the 540i wagon between the 1999 and 2003 model years, according to enthusiast forum BimmerForums. 370 were sold for the 2002 model year.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/3gQPJQP.dougs_take: This is absolutely amazing. The Hummer is already a pretty special (and highly capable) vehicle, but this is even more exciting and incredible – a Hummer with a camper on the back. The benefit, of course, is obvious: forget "Van Life"; you can use this to go deep into the wilderness – further than basically any other camper vehicle – and then camp in the back of your truck, miles from civilization of any kind. I want this. I REALLY want this. And if you're into this kind of thing, you should want it, too – because you'll never find another, and the cost to do it yourself will be astronomical.
auction_highlights: The H1 was converted into a camper with a slide-in unit from Callen Campers, which houses a queen bed, a kitchenette, a 35-gallon freshwater tank, and storage bins. Additionally, a 20-gallon auxiliary fuel tank has been added.
The seller has kept this Hummer since 2002, and has used it for remote camping in the desert.

The civilian version of the HMMWV — or Humvee — was built between 1992 and 2006 at an AM General plant in Indiana. Numerous attributes that made the original armed forces version such a success in combat were carried into the civilian model, including portal axles, a central tire inflation system, and high-mount air induction for water fording.

Power comes from a 6.5-liter Detroit Diesel turbodiesel V8, which produces 195 horsepower and 430 lb-ft of torque. Power is sent to the wheels through a 2-speed transfer case, a 4-speed General Motors automatic transmission, and Torsen differentials.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/rNAw6B6.auction_subtitle: NO RESERVE V10 Diesel Touareg with Some Modifications, Southern-Kept
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/rNAw6B6.dougs_take: The Touareg V10 TDI is a famous car in the "quirky car enthusiast" world – a midsize luxury SUV with a V10 powerplant. The mere concept of it was absurd, and it's still crazy all these years later. Now, this example can be yours; it's highly unusual and it's offered with no reserve.
auction_highlights: The attached AutoCheck history report shows this Touareg has spent its entire life registered in the South. It was sold new in Florida, it moved to Kentucky in 2007, and it has been located in North Carolina since the seller bought it in 2015.

The seller states he's an auto technician, and that he has worked on this Touareg himself since purchasing it. He adds that major work performed during his ownership includes replacing the camshafts, the fuel pumps, the water pump, many of the cooling system's hoses, both batteries, plus numerous seals and gaskets, and repairing the keyless entry unit. Most of the repairs done are detailed in a video below.

Modifications made to this Touareg include a Stage 1 tune from RocketChip. The seller also notes the diesel particulate filters have been gutted, the standard suspension height has been lowered, and the EGR valve and related piping have been removed.

Volkswagen introduced the Touareg, its first modern SUV, for the 2004 model year. Part of the brand's upmarket push, it was related to the original Porsche Cayenne, and it was marketed as a true off-roader packed with luxury features; many compared it to the Range Rover. It could cross rivers, tow a boat, or cruise on the highway for hours on end. The V10 TDI-powered model was positioned at the top of the Touareg range in the United States, where the mighty W12 engine was never available.

Power for this Touareg comes from a 5.0-liter TDI turbodiesel V10, which produces 310 horsepower and 553 lb-ft of torque when unmodified. The seller states the RocketChip Stage 1 tune bumps those figures up to 340 and 590, respectively, though a dyno sheet wasn't provided. The engine spins the 4 wheels via a 6-speed automatic transmission and Volkswagen's 4Motion permanent all-wheel-drive system, and it gives the Touareg a pickup-like 7,700-pound towing capacity.

The "E36" generation of the iconic BMW M3 was the first M3 powered by an inline-6 engine. Originally, the United States was not slated to get an M3. After owners famously banded together and demanded one be made, BMW brought the M3 to the U.S. market with a de-tuned and simpler engine than the European M3 due to emissions restrictions. It was a major commercial success for BMW, and it cemented the BMW M brand in the U.S.

The third-generation Ford Taurus SHO was intended to be a more refined sport sedan with subtler bodywork than its predecessors. It's the first and only Taurus SHO to be powered by a V8 engine, which was co-developed between Ford and Yamaha specifically for use in this car.

The SHO V8 engine began production by Ford in Windsor, Ontario, using a patented Cosworth process for the block, shipped to Japan where Yamaha completed building the engine, and then shipped to Atlanta, Georgia, for installation into the SHO.

The Hummer H2 has held its value shockingly well over the years, largely due to its expressive styling and off-road prowess – which was always better than most people thought. Released for the 2003 model year, the Hummer H2 was smaller than the war-bred H1 but it nonetheless dwarfed nearly everything else on the road. It was a burly, body-on-frame off-roader with a 40-degree approach angle and nearly 10 inches of ground clearance. The boxy body hid tried-and-true parts borrowed from Chevrolet's Suburban and Tahoe SUVs and modified for off-road use. H2 production ended in 2009.

Hummer introduced the limited-edition Victory Red package during the 2007 model year. Offered on the H2 and the H2 SUT, it added Victory Red paint, an array of body-colored trim pieces, chrome-look accents, a roof-mounted light bar, carbon fiber-look interior trim, a rear-seat entertainment system, and a rear-view camera, among other features. Most sources agree about 500 units of the H2 Victory Red were made. Pricing started at $66,030, which made it nearly $12,000 more expensive than the regular H2.
Power for this H2 comes from a 6.0-liter V8, which produces 325 horsepower and 360 lb-ft of torque. It spins the 4 wheels via a 4-speed automatic transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/36gWqNB.auction_subtitle: Ultra-Rare JDM Coupe Titled in Pennsylvania
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/36gWqNB.dougs_take: This has to be one of the single most interesting, unusual, and bizarre cars ever listed on Cars & Bids – and, therefore, I absolutely love it. This is peak 1980s Zagato, with sharp corners and squared-off details, and I truly think it looks like a concept car – but it's not a concept car, it exists, right here on Cars & Bids. Whoever buys this, I am begging you, please let me review it. I simply must know its quirks and features. I suspect they are numerous.
auction_highlights: This Stelvio AZ1 is a Japanese-spec, right-hand drive coupe that was imported to the United States by the selling dealer in 2016. It's currently titled in Pennsylvania, and its odometer shows approximately 115,300 kilometers or roughly 71,700 miles.

Originally the name for a mountain pass, and now an Alfa Romeo, the Stelvio moniker briefly denoted a Zagato-designed, Nissan-based luxury coupe built in strictly limited numbers. Its hand-built aluminum body hides a chassis shared with the upmarket "F31" Leopard, which was sold as the Infiniti M30 in the United States, while its fiberglass hood covers a turbocharged engine tuned by Autech, a subsidiary Nissan created to customize its cars.

Historians disagree about the number of Stelvio AZ1s built between 1989 and 1992. Some claim 88 units were made, while others peg the true figure at 104. Regardless, this is number 56. It cost roughly 18 million yen — twice the price of a Honda NSX — when new.

Rarity and Italian design alone couldn't justify such a high price, so the Stelvio AZ1 was lavishly equipped. It featured leather upholstery, a power-adjustable driver's seat, cruise control, and a Bose sound system, among other equipment.

Power for this Stelvio AZ1 comes from a turbocharged 3.0-liter V6, which produces 280 horsepower and 276 lb-ft of torque. Built by Nissan and tuned by Autech, the engine spins the rear wheels via a 4-speed automatic transmission with overdrive.

The Qvale Mangusta started life as the De Tomaso Biguá, a concept car introduced at the 1996 Geneva auto show. Envisioned as an Italian TVR, it was styled by Marcello Gandini and its development was largely funded by the Qvale family. De Tomaso later renamed the car Mangusta (a name first used from 1967 to 1971), but it exited the partnership shortly after production began in late 1999, allegedly due to a disagreement. Bruce Qvale put his name on the Mangusta at the last minute to recoup his investment.
Most historians agree Qvale built 284 units of the Mangusta from 1999 to 2002 in Modena, Italy. America was the car's largest market by a significant margin.
This Mangusta is one of 20 early cars signed by Bruce Qvale.

Power for this Mangusta comes from a Ford Mustang SVT Cobra-sourced 4.6-liter V8, which produces 320 horsepower and 314 lb-ft of torque. Front-mid-mounted, the engine spins the rear wheels via a 5-speed manual transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/3vJYPJZ.dougs_take: The Passat W8 is one of the most bizarre and mystifying decisions in the entire modern history of Volkswagen – and they made some REALLY strange ones in the mid-2000s, including a V10-powered Touareg and a 12-cylinder luxury sedan. Volkswagen sold 4,931 units of the Passat W8 in the United States between the 2002 and 2004 model years, according to enthusiast forum VWVortex. 3,704 of these were sedans, and the rest were wagons, making this Passat a highly unusual sight.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/KVpJMpL.dougs_take: Ahhh, yes: the famous Volkswagen Touareg V10 TDI, which was exactly what it sounds like: a Volkswagen Touareg with ... a V10 engine. Surprisingly, perhaps, it was just as ridiculous then as it is now. These had big power (310 horses) but REALLY big torque (553 lb-ft) and they could pull practically anything; at 132,000 miles, this one is relatively lower-mileage than most V10 Touareg models I see. It's still quite an amazing thing to behold – a relic from an era when Volkswagen made some really impressive, unusual, but car enthusiast-friendly decisions with its products.
auction_highlights: The attached AutoCheck history report shows no accidents, and it notes this Touareg was sold new in Arizona. It moved to California in 2010, and it has been registered in Oregon since 2014. The odometer currently displays about 132,700 miles.

Service records included in the gallery list most of the maintenance and repairs performed on this Touareg during the 2010s. The driveshaft was replaced in June 2020, 3 brake vacuum lines were changed in October 2019, and new front upper control arms were installed in December 2016. The engine was replaced with a new unit by a Volkswagen dealer at about 45,000 miles in February 2010. The seller states the previous owner damaged the original engine while attempting to drive through a flood.

Volkswagen introduced the Touareg, its first modern SUV, for the 2004 model year. Part of the brand's upmarket push, it was related to the original Porsche Cayenne, and it was marketed as a true off-roader packed with luxury features; many compared it to the Land Rover Range Rover. It could cross rivers, tow a boat, or cruise on the highway for hours on end. The V10 TDI-powered model was positioned at the top of the Touareg range in the United States, where the mighty W12 engine was never available.

Power for this Touareg comes from a 5.0-liter V10 TDI turbodiesel engine, which produces 310 horsepower and 553 lb-ft of torque. It spins the 4 wheels via a 6-speed automatic transmission and Volkswagen's 4Motion permanent all-wheel-drive system, and it gives the Touareg a pickup-like 7,700-pound towing capacity.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/rk65x1m.dougs_take: The 190E 2.3-16 is a special car, and we've sold a few of them – but this one, in particular, is a gem. This 190E is a gray-market car, meaning it was built to European specifications and imported to America when it was nearly new. It retains European-spec headlights, corner lights, and bumpers, but it has been federalized so its instrument cluster displays miles.

The attached AutoCheck history report starts in 2001, and it notes this 190E has been titled in Arizona since. The Carfax report included in the gallery confirms this history. Called W201 internally, and colloquially known as the "Baby Benz," the Mercedes-Benz 190 arrived in the United States for the 1984 model year. https://carsandbids.com/auctions/3O7VZdm.auction_subtitle: European-Spec V8-Powered Coupe Titled in Arizona
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/3O7VZdm.dougs_take: These big W126-body coupes were absolutely boss – all of the durability and quality of the W126 sedan, plus the more attractive look of the coupe. auction_highlights: This 500SEC is a European-spec model sold new near Kiel, Germany, and imported to the United States in 2000. European-spec SECs wore market-specific headlights and smaller bumpers than their American-spec counterparts, and this 500 retains these parts. It also kept the metric temperature gauge, and its climate control panel is labeled in German.
The attached AutoCheck history report starts in 2000, and it lists no accidents.

Known as the C126 internally, the SEC was launched for the 1983 model year as the W126's coupe counterpart. While buyers in America were initially asked to settle for the 155-horsepower 380 model, Europeans could order the 500 variant that offered a more powerful engine, and the power disparity helped fuel a lucrative gray market. 500 sedans and coupes finally arrived in America for 1984, and both body styles gained an even bigger V8 for 1986. SEC sales ended after the 1991 model year.
Power for this 500 SEC comes from a 5.0-liter V8, which produces 228 horsepower and 299 lb-ft of torque. It spins the rear wheels via a 4-speed automatic transmission.

The interior presents well, the exterior presents well... this isn't just a Yugo, it's a NICE Yugo – and if you're looking to buy a Yugo, your search is over!
auction_highlights: The attached AutoCheck history report shows this GV was registered in Florida during most of the 2010s. It's currently titled in Massachusetts.
The 5-digit odometer shows 1,709 miles, but the total mileage is unknown. AutoCheck warns of a mileage discrepancy in 2019. It lists the GV's mileage as 50,692 in 2010.

In the United States, Yugo's convoluted story began when Malcolm Bricklin of Subaru fame hired former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger as a consultant to launch the nation's cheapest new car. Yugo sales started for the 1986 model year, and it was reasonably popular until owners discovered what made it so cheap. The firm filed for bankruptcy in 1989, it returned shortly after, and it left for good in 1992.
GV stands for Great Value. It was manufactured in the former Yugoslavia, where it was known as the Zastava Koral. Mechanically, it's closely related to the Fiat 127.

Although widely maligned as one of the worst cars ever made due to its relatively slow engine, a build quality best described as approximate, and hit-or-miss reliability, the GV is has developed a cult following by morphing into a classic that's rare, cheap, and quirky.
Power for this Yugo comes from a 1.1-liter 4-cylinder, which produces 52 horsepower and 52 lb-ft of torque. It spins the front wheels via a 4-speed manual transmission.
known_flaws: The attached AutoCheck history report states this GV collided with a tree in Ohio in 1996.
The 5-digit odometer displays 1,709 miles, but this GV's total mileage is unknown. AutoCheck notes an odometer discrepancy in October 2019.
Passenger-side mirror missing

Powered by the beloved "S62" 4.9-liter V8, the E39 M5 produces 394 horsepower and 368 lb-ft of torque. Power is shuttled to the rear wheels via a 6-speed manual Getrag 420G transmission.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/r4V8E1O.auction_subtitle: NO RESERVE Early W124 with a 5-Speed Manual Transmission
https://carsandbids.com/auctions/r4V8E1O.dougs_take: Now this is an unusual one. A W124 300E isn't that special, on the surface, but this one is highly unusual due to its transmission – a 5-speed manual! Even by the W124 era, Mercedes-Benz knew its customers were more of the "automatic" type, and they didn't make many manuals – and this was the last E-Class offered with a manual in North America. It's rare to find one, and I'm thrilled to offer such an unusual car (especially with no reserve!) on Cars & Bids.
auction_highlights: This 300E is fitted with the rare and desirable 5-speed manual transmission.

Well-equipped from the factory, this 300E features headlight wipers, power-operated front seats, heated door mirrors, a sunroof, air conditioning, and cruise control. Modifications are limited to a Denon cassette player and a set of new Coco floor mats.

Service records detail most of the maintenance and repairs performed on this 300E. According to the seller, the list of parts recently changed includes the tires, the rear control arm bushings, the overvoltage regulator, and the shifter bushings.

Mercedes-Benz introduced the W124 for the 1986 model year as a replacement for the W123. At launch, the range included the gasoline-powered 300E and the diesel-burning 300D. Both came standard with a 4-speed automatic transmission, but 300E buyers could request a 5-speed manual in 1986 and 1988, though very few did. Mercedes-Benz turned the W124 into the first E-Class for 1994, and production ended after 1995.
Power for this 300E comes from a 3.0-liter straight-6, which produces 177 horsepower and 188 lb-ft of torque. It spins the rear wheels via a 5-speed manual transmission.
auction_equipment: Memory function for the driver's seat
known_flaws: The attached AutoCheck history report dates back to 1996 and notes that this 300E collided with another vehicle in New York in 2004. It was involved in a second accident in New Jersey in 2014.

Some modifications to this Porsche 924 S include a 9Tuning ECU chip and an Alpine stereo with Rockford Fosgate speakers.
The Porsche 924 was the first front-engine, rear-wheel-drive Porsche production model when it came out in 1976. The 924 S used a de-tuned version of the base engine in the higher-performance 944.
This 924 S is powered by a 2.5-liter inline-4 engine, which produces 150 horsepower and 142 lb-ft of torque.
